channel.title: Laptop
channel.description:
Well it's come time for me to get a laptop to use while I'm on the bus/train. That's 2 hours of wasted time where I could be doing things like modeling and video editing.
I've been looking at low priced laptops (<600) and I've come across a few but I just found a Gateway that seems to kick the other's asses in a lot of ways. I need suggestions.
HP G60T = ~540 15.6" Display Intel Core 2 Duo T6400 2.0Ghz Vista Home Basic Edition 32-Bit 2GB RAM 320GB 5400RPM SATA
Dell Inspiron 15 = ~530 15.6" Display Intel Core Duo 2.16 GHz Vista 2GB RAM 160GB SATA
Gateway T-6859u = ~500 14.1" Display Intel Core 2 Duo T6400 2.0GHz Vista Home Premium 64 bit 4GB RAM 320GB SATA
Is the smaller display worth the rest of it owning the other laptops? Or do you know of any other kickass laptops for around 500? Or do you know of any place that sells laptops without shit preinstalled like Vista, MS Office, etc so it's cheaper?

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:26, topic:282921”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=373851.msg2827462#msg2827462 date=1245128939]

Anyone know which is better?

AMD Turion 64 X2 TL-60 2GHz
Intel Pentium Dual Core T3400 2.16GHz

I have no experience with any laptop or low end CPUs, and all my CPUs I use daily are Intel Quads.

Intel over AMD any day. AMD processors tend to run hotter, which is especially bad for laptops.

Apparently Intel is better than AMD for speed, but I have to say Intel runs way hotter. My P3 Laptop idles at appx 70C. My AMD 2.7ghz DC idles at around 35C with the standard fan. BUT my server idles at around 25C a cpu with just one big fan stuck over the top of the two.
[/quote]Depends what AMD cpu you use. My Phenom II runs at 36C idle clocked from 2.8ghz to 3.4ghz with stock cooler.[/quote]
Phenom II was a success and much different from the past processors.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:19, topic:282921”]Mopar is that directed towards me?

That’s almost the exact same thing as the Gateway I was looking at, it’s just $50 cheaper, AMD instead of Intel, and -1GB of RAM.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: June 09, 2009, 10:45:58 pm[/size][hr]
Also, how big is a 14.1" laptop? My sister’s is a 15.6", and it feels pretty big. I wouldn’t think a 14.1" would be a lot smaller, but my dad said it’s really small.

Any size comparison pictures or something to put it in scale for me?[/quote]
14.1" isn’t bad (or as small as you think).

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I was going to buy a “cheap laptop” but now I decided that a Netbook would be more appropriate for my needs however I came over a pretty good Acer.

http://www.acerdirect.co.uk/Acer_Aspire_5735Z_Laptop_LX.AU50X.018/version.asp
This has a 15.6" Inch 16:9 aspect ratio screen. Great for movies!

But I am slightly confused weather it has a Core 2 or Pentium Dual Core Processor???

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:12, topic:282921”]Netbook, what’s the difference?

The thing is, I’ll have an hour bus ride and a thirty minute bus ride to and from school. I’m at school for quite a while. I can charge it then.

I doubt I’ll have internet while on the bus or train, but I will at school.

The laptops I’ve been looking at are mainly used for multimedia, casual gaming, and editing. One of the models was tested and got 119 minutes of watching HD movies.

I thought the battery would do alright.[/quote]

Watching movies is much different than video editing and modeling. I doubt you would have quite an hour while doing such things, it’s just something to think about.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

SomethingToHide:

But that’s not really what I need. The only thing that would be good for is internet browsing, and I won’t have wireless internet on the bus or train, which is when I’ll be using it.

So then go with your laptop or the one I suggested.

Read full topic

I thought the battery would do alright.[/quote]
Netbook: Slower processor, less cache & ram, longer batter life, lightweight.

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:282921”]Well, normally for mobility like being on a train, I would say go with a netbook. But for modeling and video editing you need the CPU and RAM, don’t you? Not to mention that will eat battery no matter what. If you can get wireless internet, I would suggest a netbook, you can VNC into your desktop which can be used for the heavy lifting.

Really what your wanting to do will not work well on a battery at all.[/quote]
That’s actually a good idea - if you’re looking for long battery life and simple tasks go get a laptop (netbook) with an atom.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Well, normally for mobility like being on a train, I would say go with a netbook. But for modeling and video editing you need the CPU and RAM, don’t you? Not to mention that will eat battery no matter what. If you can get wireless internet, I would suggest a netbook, you can VNC into your desktop which can be used for the heavy lifting.

Really what your wanting to do will not work well on a battery at all.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

SomethingToHide:

http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/searchtools/item-details.asp?EdpNo=4545452&SRCCODE=CNETFEED&cm_mmc_o=2mHCjC2WHaCjCVqHCjCdwwp

Gateway will have more proprietary hardware.
Lenovo processor can handle higher temperatures
Lenovo processor has higher multiplier
Lenovo can have a higher speed hard disk, I really recommend this (increases HDD life)
Lenovo/IBM can easily be repaired (pretty generic parts)
Gateway states ‘Intel Centrino Processor Technology’ which doesn’t make much sense because it’s a mobile Core2 Duo processor.

I’ll admit, it’s a good deal; but Lenovo in my opinion wins long term for durability, hardware support, & easily accessible hardware repair.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:3, topic:282921”]Just looked. I’ve looked at Lenovos before, but didn’t look into customization. The only thing is, if the Gateway is $70 cheaper and has double the RAM, space, and a 64bit OS, why get the Lenovo?

My sister just got a Lenovo, I don’t know the specs on it or anything, but it’s normally a $1100 laptop and my dad picked it up for $500.[/quote]
They last long, rugged, can customize out the wazoo, they put good hardware inside, they don’t hide any specs.

Read full topic
